shoot_on_an_angle::title: Shoot on an Angle
shoot_on_an_angle::tip_collection::tips[: Tip: Capture a great moment, but be sure it relates clearly to your story.
Tip: Don't crop too tightly, get close, but capture the whole subject.
Tip: the viewer won't know anything about your story that you don't show them in the photograph.
Tip: Even if time is limited, make a plan, do not shoot everything you see.
Tip: Images on a mobile will be small. Compose with that in mind.
Tip: Get as close to your subject as possible.
Tip: Pick your moment carefully. Avoid distracting objects or people moving through your frame.
Tip: Are there any distracting objects between you and subject in your frame?
Tip: Distracting objects in the background can ruin a well-framed foreground.
Tip: Use the whole frame to tell your story. Not just the center.
Tip: Ensure foreground objects are not too close unless you want them out of focus.
Tip: Repetitive actions provide the opportunity to capture the moment from different angles.
Tip: Do not cut hands or faces with the edge of the frame, if possible.
Tip: Allow important subjects to complete inside the frame.
Tip: Can you change your angle to include more context?
Tip: When shooting multiple characters or objects, place one in the background to create a sense of depth.
Tip: Subjects in the background must not appear too small or their importance may be lost.
Tip: Good photography is all about light. Are you using available light as best you can?
Tip: Think about timing and location when trying to capture peak action.
Tip: Try to push the shutter button just before the intended moment, to give the camera time to react.
Tip: The horizon can be place on the top or bottom horizontal gridline.
Tip: Even if you will only use one image in your story, shoot a variety of images to choose from.
Tip: "If your picture's not good enough, you're not close enough." - Robert Capa
